choices.text: Causative organism shows corkscrew motility
Incubation period is 2-5 days
Extragenital syphilitic chancre can occur over fingers
Dory flop sign can be seen in uncircumcised males

questions.text: A commercial sex worker presents with an indurated, painless ulcer over her vulva. On examination painless inguinal lymphadenopathy is also present. Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding this disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incubation period is 2-5 days.

 

Option B:

 

Incubation period is 2-5 days
 

  • With the clinical scenario given, the diagnosis would be Primary syphilis. Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum.
  • Treponema pallidum has corkscrew motility as seen below.

 

 

  • The incubation period of syphilis is 9-90 days and varies inversely with the size of the Spirochaete inoculum.
  • Extragenital syphilitic chancre can occur over fingers, hands, and the oral cavity.

 

Extragenital syphilitic chancre over Lips

 

 

  • The Dory flop sign is described in an uncircumcised male with an indurated lesion of primary syphilis on the underside of the coronal sulcus.
  • Here, prepucial retraction causes the foreskin to flip suddenly.
     

Prepucial chancre leading to Dory flop sign

 

Fig: Indurated ulcer (primary chancre) on the prepuce

 

  • The Dory flop sign can help distinguish chancres from other nonindurated causes of genital ulcer disease, such as Herpes simplex virus infection and chancroid.
  • It is named after the movement of a dory, a small wooden fishing boat, which flips suddenly when overturned.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The incubation period of syphilis is approximately 3 weeks to 3 months after exposure.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 29, Page no’s 29.7

choices.text: Coppery red coloured, non-pruritic lesions with Symmetrical distribution
Vesiculobullous eruptions over skin
Non-Scarring moth-eaten alopecia
Buschke-Ollendorff sign

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with a hyperpigmented rash over his palms and soles. On further probing, he admits that his partner was recently diagnosed with syphilis and he himself had an ulcer on his penis a few months back. Which is NOT a characteristic feature of the secondary syphilis stage?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vesiculobullous eruptions over skin

 

Option B:

 

Vesiculobullous eruptions over skin

 

Secondary syphilis is suggested by a recent rash and a history of penile ulcers in a partner with syphilis. A non-infectious maculopapular rash is usually the earliest manifestation.

 

It typically appears 8 weeks after the initial infection as a result of widespread treponema dissemination.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Rashes in secondary syphilis have three common features:

 

  • Non-pruritic
  • Coppery red color
  • Symmetrically distributed
    • Due to a lack of treponemes, cutaneous lesions from secondary syphilis are not contagious.
    • The only exceptions are mucous patches and condyloma lata, both of which are very contagious.

 

Option B: Vesiculobullous lesions are not seen in secondary syphilis. They are a feature of early congenital syphilis.


The following are some signs of secondary syphilis:
 

  • The earliest rash is the macular or roseolar rash. Leucoderma Syphiliticum, also known as the necklace of Venus, is a hypopigmentation that develops around the neck as it fades.
  • The palms and soles are covered in a papule-like rash, and later, nummular lesions with scales that resemble psoriasis are visible. The scales are simple to remove because of the lesions' serous discharge.

 

Option C. Syphilitic alopecia or moth-eaten alopecia as seen below is a form of non-scarring patchy hair loss.
 

 

Option D: Olendroff probe sign or Buschke-Ollendorff sign refers to the deep dermal tenderness elicited by pressing the Papular lesions of secondary syphilis with a pinhead, when the patient winces with pain.

 

  • Although ulceration is uncommon, papules on the oral mucosa can coalesce to form the so called "snail-track" lesions, as seen below.


 

  • Condyloma lata refers to moist, well-demarcated papules and plaques which are seen on the genitalia.
  • They are highly infectious.
     

Condyloma lata lesions:
 


Condyloma acuminata / anogenital warts are caused by HPV (Human Papillomavirus) virus. They are different from Condyloma lata.
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The typical rash of secondary syphilis is coppery red, non-pruritic, and symmetrically distributed, often involving the palms and soles.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 29, Page nos 29.10-13

choices.text: Sexual contact
Blood transfusion
Endemic disease
Skin to skin contact

questions.text: A 49-year-old man presents with secondary syphilis-like features He has no history of chancre. On examination, he has epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the likely cause of this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood transfusion

 

Option B:

 

Blood transfusion

 

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of secondary syphilis. The lack of chancre is indicative of syphilis d'emblee, a rare form of the disease that is spread through blood transfusion.

 

In this condition, the disease directly manifests in the secondary stage and there are no primary lesions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sexual contact:

 

  • While sexual contact is the most common route of transmission for syphilis, the absence of a chance (primary syphilis lesion) might suggest a non-sexual mode of transmission in this case. Primary syphilis can go unnoticed, but in the case presented, another route of transmission is suggested.

 

Option C. Endemic disease: 

 

  • While syphilis is endemic in certain populations, the term 'endemic disease' typically refers to diseases that are constantly present in a particular region and doesn't imply a transmission route.

 

Option D. Skin to skin contact:

 

  • Although Treponema pallidum can be transmitted through close physical contact, this route is less likely to cause syphilis without a chancre being present, and epitrochlear lymphadenopathy is not typically associated with such transmission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary syphilis without a history of chancre could suggest a transmission route other than sexual contact, such as a blood transfusion, especially if there is evidence of systemic involvement like epitrochlear lymphadenopathy.

 

Ref: online source https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3401849/

choices.text: Vesiculobullous lesions
Hepatosplenomegaly
Rhinitis
Seventh nerve palsy

questions.text: All of the following can be seen associated with Early congenital syphilis EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Seventh nerve palsy

 

Option D. Seventh nerve palsy

 

  • Early congenital syphilis may present with vesiculobullous lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, and rhinitis.
  • Seventh nerve palsy is not typically a feature of early congenital syphilis but may be associated with late manifestations of the disease

 

Explanation:

 

  • Syphilitic rhinitis, commonly referred to as "snuffles," is frequently the first and most prevalent symptom of early congenital syphilis.
  • A profuse, serous nasal discharge with a significant amount of Treponema pallidum is how it presents.
  • Snuffles, Syphilitic pemphigus & Hepatosplenomegaly form the triad of Early Congenital syphilis.
  • Due to the destruction of the nose's bone and cartilage in later stages, a saddle nose may develop.
  • Congenital syphilis can spread intrapartum through lesions in the mother's genitalia or trans placentally from an infected mother. The primary and secondary stages of the disease are when the risk is greatest. It can result in fetal death or congenital syphilis in a live birth if untreated.
  • The onset of congenital syphilis can be early or late. Early disease manifests within two years, while late disease does so after three years.

 

Late congenital syphilis has Hutchinson's triad which includes the following:

 

1. Interstitial keratitis

2. Eighth nerve deafness

3. Hutchinson's teeth

 

Hutchinson teeth are abnormal permanent upper central incisors that are peg-shaped and notched.

 

 

  • Seventh nerve palsy is NOT a feature of early congenital syphilis.

 


 

  • It is associated with 8th nerve deafness, along with tinnitus and vertigo.
     

Educational Objective:
 

  • Early congenital syphilis may present with vesiculobullous lesions, hepatosplenomegaly, and rhinitis.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition Chapter 29, Page nos 29.28-29

choices.text: Scurvy
Early congenital syphilis
Late congenital syphilis
None of the above

questions.text: Wimberger sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Early congenital syphilis

 

Option B: Early congenital syphilis

 

Wimberger sign is the localized bilateral metaphyseal destruction of the medial proximal tibia.

 

It is a feature of Early congenital syphilis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Scurvy:

 

  • Scurvy is associated with vitamin C deficiency and can lead to various bone abnormalities, but Wimberger sign is not characteristic of scurvy. In scurvy, you might see Scorbutic rosary or Frankel's sign, which are different from the Wimberger sign.

 

Scurvy: Wimberger ring sign refers to a circular calcification surrounding the osteoporotic epiphyseal center of ossification in scurvy, which may result from bleeding.
 

 

https://radiopaedia.org/cases/illustration-of-scurvy-signs-1

 

Option C. Late congenital syphilis:

 

  • Late congenital syphilis can present with several bone deformities, such as saber shins, but the Wimberger sign is specifically associated with early congenital syphilis.
  • Musculoskeletal system signs & Symptoms in Late congenital syphilis:
     
  • Cluttons joints refer to painless symmetrical swelling of the knees.
     
  • Higoumenaki's sign is the unilateral enlargement of the sternal end of the clavicle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Wimberger sign is a radiological feature typically associated with early congenital syphilis, characterized by symmetrical destruction of the medial portion of the proximal tibial metaphyses.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition

Chapter 29, Page nos 29.30-32

Online: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21498006/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1047420/

choices.text: Seen in primary syphilis
Noninfectious
Also called as Relapsing syphilis
Recurring chancre at the site of previously healed chancre

questions.text: Which of the following is FALSE about Chancre redux?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Non infectious

 

Option B: Non infectious

 

  • Chancre redux, also known as relapsing syphilis, is the recurrence of a syphilitic chancre at the site of the previously healed initial lesion and is indeed infectious.

 

Explanation:

 

Chancre redux is seen in primary syphilis and is highly infectious.

It must not be confused with Pseudochancre redux.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chancre redux, also known as relapsing syphilis, is the recurrence of a syphilitic chancre at the site of the previously healed initial lesion and is indeed infectious.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition

Chapter 29, Page nos 29.20 & chapter 111 pg no 111.24-25

choices.text: Syphilis & VDRL
Syphilis & Dark field microscopy
Chancroid & Gram Stain
LGV & NAAT

questions.text: A woman with multiple sexual partners with painless Genital ulcer & associated Painless Lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis & what is the Investigation of choice for this stage of the disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Syphilis & dark field microscopy

 

Option B: Syphilis & dark field microscopy

 

The diagnosis of primary syphilis is suggested by a painless genital ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy, with dark field microscopy being the investigation of choice to directly visualize Treponema pallidum spirochetes

 

Explanation:

 

  • With the clinical scenario given, the diagnosis would be Primary syphilis. Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum.

 

  • Primary syphilis commonly presents as a papule on external genitalia that rapidly ulcerates to form a primary chancre.

 

  • Primary chancre: Painless, indurated, button-like ulcer with painless inguinal lymphadenopathy.

 

 

  • Microscopically, Treponema pallidum is identified with a characteristic wave-like appearance on dark field microscopy.

 

  • Treponema is a corkscrew organism. The coils are very close and regular with around 7 to 8 coils per diameter of a red blood corpuscle. It rotates along its long axis and appears to screw slowly forwards and backwards.

 

 

Option C: Chancroid presents with multiple, soft painful ulcers and unilateral tender lymphadenopathy.

 

Microscopy of chancroid lesions shows H. ducreyi in a sheet-like or school of fish or railroad pattern.

 

Option D: LGV presents with a painless or painful Transient Genital ulcer later followed by Painful lymphadenopathy. NAAT is used for its diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The diagnosis of primary syphilis is suggested by a painless genital ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy, with dark field microscopy being the investigation of choice to directly visualize Treponema pallidum spirochetes.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition

Chapter 29, Page nos 29.7

choices.text: It is triggered by lipoproteins
Penicillin cannot be used in future
Fever usually comes down within 8 hours
D Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction occurs within 24 hours of penicillin therapy

questions.text: After 14 hours of receiving Injection Penicillin for her early latent syphilis, a 35-year-old woman suddenly develops a high-grade fever, myalgia, and bone pain. Which of the following statements is FALSE with respect to her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Penicillin cannot be used in future

 

Option B: Penicillin cannot be used in future

 

  • The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a temporary reaction to antibiotic therapy for syphilis, characterized by fever, myalgia, and bone pain, and is not a contraindication to future penicillin use.

 

Explanation:

 

  • A febrile reaction occurring within 24 hours of penicillin therapy for syphilis is suggestive of Jarisch-Herxheimer's reaction.
  • Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is self-limiting and is due to lipoprotein release from the dying treponemes, which trigger cytokine release.
  • The patient presents with flu-like symptoms and exacerbation of skin lesions. Fever rarely lasts more than 8 hours. Symptoms may be controlled by antipyretics. It is not a contraindication for penicillin use in the future.
  • Penicillin allergy is a contraindication for further use. JH reactions must be differentiated from penicillin allergy.
  • Constitutional Symptoms such as Fever, Joint Pain, Hypotension along with Worsening of Skin Lesions. Treatment : Symptomatic

 

Allergic reactions can be early or late as follows:

 

  • Early type- anaphylaxis within 1 hour of the first dose.
  • Late type- rash after several doses of penicillin.

 

In Jarisch-Herxheimer's reaction, Corticosteroids are only indicated in pregnant women and patients with neurosyphilis in whom the reaction can be more serious and life-threatening sequelae.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is a temporary reaction to antibiotic therapy for syphilis, characterized by fever, myalgia, and bone pain, and is not a contraindication to future penicillin use.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition

Chapter 29, Page nos 29.26

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page 3167

choices.text: Chickenpox – 7 days
Hepatitis A - 10 days
SARS – 20 days
Syphilis – 90 days

questions.text: Which of the following disease is correctly correlated with its incubation period?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis – 90 days

 

Option D: Syphilis – 90 days

 

  • When considering incubation periods for various diseases, it's important to remember that syphilis can have a lengthy incubation period of up to 90 days before the first symptoms appear, which can include a painless ulcer known as a chancre.

 

Explanation:

 

  • The incubation period for syphilis can range from 10 to 90 days, with an average of 21 days.
  • However, symptoms can sometimes take up to 90 days to appear, which is why this option is correct.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Syphilis can have a lengthy incubation period of up to 90 days before the first symptoms appear, which can include a painless ulcer known as a chancre.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, chapter 14 Page no 265

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.3

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1447

choices.text: Primary Syphilis
Secondary Syphilis
Latent Syphilis
Congenital Syphilis

questions.text: Kassowitz law is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Congenital Syphilis

 

Option D: Congenital Syphilis

 

  • Kassowitz's law is indeed related to Congenital Syphilis.
  • An untreated syphilitic mother tends to improve on her past performances.
  • Kassowitz's law pertains to the transmission of syphilis from mother to child and the timing of infection in relation to the stage of pregnancy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Primary Syphilis –

 

  • This stage involves the initial infection and genital ulceration but does not relate to Kassowitz's law, which is specific to congenital syphilis.

 

Option B: Secondary Syphilis –
 

  • Secondary syphilis refers to the stage with systemic spread of the infection, characterized by rash and lymphadenopathy, not congenital transmission.

 

Option C: Latent Syphilis –

 

  • Latent syphilis is the stage where the disease is not active but remains in the body. This also does not pertain to congenital syphilis.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Kassowitz's law is associated with congenital syphilis, highlighting the impact of the timing of maternal infection on the clinical presentation of syphilis in the newborn.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, chapter 15 Page no 290

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.27

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1455

Online resources:

https://jsstd.org/laws-and-signs-of-congenital-syphilis/#:~:text=LAWS%20OF%20CONGENITAL%20SYPHILIS&text=DIDAY%2DKASSOWITZ%20LAW%20(1876),in%20later%20pregnancies%20becomes%20less.

choices.text: Only 1 & 2 are correct.
Only 1 is correct.
Only 2 is correct.
Only 2, 3, 4 are correct.

questions.text:
Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is due to?

 

  1. IFN Alpha
  2. IL – 6
  3. TNF Alpha
  4. IL – 8
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only 2, 3, 4 are correct

 

Option D: Only 2, 3, 4 are correct

 

Explanation:

 

Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction

 

  • This is an acute febrile reaction that often includes headache, myalgia, fever, and other symptoms.
  • It typically occurs after antibiotic treatment for certain bacterial infections, notably syphilis, Lyme disease, and other spirochetal infections.
  • The reaction is believed to be caused by the release of cytokines from the body's immune system in response to endotoxins released from the death of harmful bacteria following antibiotic treatment.
  • IL-6, TNF Alpha, and IL-8 are cytokines that are known to play a role in the inflammatory response, including fever and inflammation, which are characteristic of the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction.
  • They are part of the body's immune response to infection and are released in larger quantities when large numbers of bacteria are killed off suddenly, as can happen with the initiation of antibiotic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction is associated with the rapid destruction of bacteria following antibiotic treatment and is mediated by the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6, TNF Alpha, and IL-8.
  • It is important to be aware of this reaction when treating bacterial infections that can release endotoxins, as the symptoms can mimic infection or sepsis and must be managed appropriately.

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, chapter 17 Page no 322

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 26.69

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1458

choices.text: Chancroid
Granuloma inguinale
Herpes genitalis
Syphilis

questions.text: What is the cause of painless ulcer associated with painless inguinal lymph node?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syphilis

 

Option D: Syphilis.

 

  • Caused by Treponema pallidum, is characterized in its primary stage by a painless ulcer (chancre) and non-tender lymphadenopathy which aligns with the presentation described in the question.
  • Syphilitic ulcer is also called Hard Chancre/Hunterian Chancre. Description:
    • 1) Single ulcer
    • 2) Clean based
    • 3) Hard Indurated
    • 4) Non-Tender
    • 5) Does not bleed on Touch 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Chancroid

 

  • This is incorrect because Chancroid, caused by Haemophilus ducreyi, typically presents with painful genital ulcers and may be associated with painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, not painless

 

Option B: Granuloma inguinale / Donovanosis

 

  • This is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis, leads to painless genital ulcers, but it is often associated with beefy red granulation tissue and not classically linked with lymphadenopathy.

 

Option C: Herpes genitalis

 

  • This is incorrect because genital herpes, caused by the Herpes Simplex Virus, typically results in painful ulcers and inguinal lymph nodes are often tender.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a patient presenting with a painless genital ulcer and painless inguinal lymph nodes, primary syphilis is the most likely diagnosis, while other STIs like chancroid and herpes genitalis usually present with painful ulcers and/or tender lymphadenopathy.

 

 

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, chapter 45 Page no 771

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.4

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1447

choices.text: Secondary syphilis
Lichen planus
Scabies
Psoriasis

questions.text: A 45-year-old truck driver with a history of multiple sex partners presented to the dermatological department, as shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secondary syphilis

 

Option A Secondary syphilis

 

  • The diagnosis of the image which is showing hyperpigmented macules, suggestive of palmoplantar syphillides is secondary syphilis
  • This is characterized by systemic manifestations, including a rash which may cover the entire body or be localized to the palms and soles, mucous patches, condylomata lata, and lymphadenopathy.
  • This stage reflects the hematogenous spread of Treponema pallidum.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lichen Planus

 

  • It presents pruritic, purple, polygonal, planar papules and plaques with fine scales.
  • Wickham striae, reticular white lines on the surface of the lesions, are characteristic.

 

Option C. Scabies

 

  • It is an intensely pruritic skin condition caused by the mite Sarcoptes scabiei, leading to burrows, erythematous papules, and excoriation, typically involving the web spaces of the fingers, wrists, and waistline.

 

Option D Psoriasis

 

  • This typically presents well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, often on extensor surfaces and the scalp. Nail changes and joint involvement can also occur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Secondary syphilis is identified by characteristic systemic rash, which often involves the palms and soles, and its association with a history of sexual contact, which can include multiple partners.

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 270

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.10

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1458

choices.text: Dark field microscope
Electron microscopy
Fluorescent microscope
None of the above

questions.text: A truck driver comes with complaints of painless, indurated genital ulcer after unprotected / unsafe intercourse. The motility of the causative agent can be detected by which type of microscope.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dark field microscopy

 

Option A. Dark field microscopy

 

  • Dark field microscopy is the method of choice for visualizing Treponema pallidum, the spirochete bacterium that causes syphilis, which typically presents with a painless genital ulcer.

 

 

  • This method allows for the observation of live bacteria and their corkscrew motility, which are not visible on a regular light microscope due to their thin nature.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Electron microscopy

 

  • While electron microscopy provides detailed ultrastructural images of organisms, it is not used in the routine clinical evaluation of genital ulcers due to its complexity and cost. Moreover, it cannot be used to observe live bacterial motility, which is key in the diagnosis of syphilis.

 

Option C. Fluorescent microscope

 

  • Fluorescent microscopy is used in conjunction with specific fluorescent markers or antibodies that can bind to a pathogen of interest. It is not typically used to observe bacterial motility or to diagnose syphilis.

 

Option D. None of the above

 

  • This option is incorrect because dark field microscopy is indeed a suitable method to observe the motility of spirochetes such as Treponema pallidum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dark field microscopy is the appropriate technique to visualize the motility of Treponema pallidum, the causative agent of syphilis, which presents as a painless, indurated genital ulcer.

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 304

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.27

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1449

choices.text: Loss of density on medial side of upper end of tibia
Hutchinson's teeth
Cluttons joints
Unilateral thickening of medial third of clavicle

questions.text: Which of the following is typical of early stage of congenital syphilis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of density on medial side of upper end of tibia

 

Option A. Loss of density on medial side of upper end of tibia

 

  • This finding, known as Wimberger's sign, is typical of the early stage of congenital syphilis.

 

 

  • It indicates osteochondritis, which is often seen within the first six months of life, and can be symptomatic or only detected on radiological examination.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Hutchinson's teeth

 

  • Hutchinson's teeth refer to peg-shaped, notched permanent incisors that are a feature of late congenital syphilis, not the early stage.

 

 

 

  • These dental anomalies typically become apparent when the permanent teeth erupt.

 

Option C. Clutton's joints

 

  • Clutton's joints, which refer to painless synovitis and effusions of the knees, are also a sign of late congenital syphilis and not typically seen in the early stage.

 

Option D. Unilateral thickening of medial third of clavicle

 

  • Unilateral thickening of the medial third of the clavicle, or Higouménakis’ sign, is another late manifestation of congenital syphilis.
  • It is not a characteristic feature of the early stage of the disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wimberger's sign is indicative of the early stage of congenital syphilis.
  • Early diagnosis and appropriate management of congenital syphilis are crucial to prevent long-term complications.

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 291

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.29

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1456

choices.text: Give injection aqueous penicillin to baby
Perform serum VDRL of the baby
Perform CSF VDRL of the baby
Wait and Watch

questions.text: A 29-years-old pregnant female's routine investigations showed VDRL positive with 1:16 titres. TPHA was also positive. The pregnant female was adequately treated with injection benzathine penicillin. What is the next step of management for the baby?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Perform serum VDRL of the baby

 

Option B. Perform serum VDRL of the baby

 

  • Since the mother had a positive VDRL and TPHA, indicating syphilis, the baby must be tested after birth to rule out congenital syphilis.
  • The serum VDRL is a standard test to screen for syphilis in the newborn.
     

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Give injection aqueous penicillin to baby.

 

  • Prophylactic treatment with penicillin is not recommended without evidence of congenital syphilis.
  • The baby should be tested first before any treatment is given.

 

Option C. Perform CSF VDRL of the baby.

 

  • A CSF VDRL test is used to diagnose neurosyphilis.
  • This would only be necessary if the baby's serum VDRL is positive or if there are clinical signs suggesting neurosyphilis.

 

Option D. Wait and Watch.

 

  • It is not appropriate to simply observe the baby without testing, given the risk of congenital syphilis.
  • Early diagnosis and treatment, if necessary, are crucial.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The screening a newborn for congenital syphilis when the mother has a history of the infection, is done by performing a serum VDRL test.

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 297

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.34

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1459

choices.text: Congenital syphilis
Congenital toxoplasmosis
Congenital rubella
Congenital cytomegalovirus

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl presents with a 6-month history of declining visual acuity and behavioural changes at school. Her mother states that the child had a home birth without any medical interventions and did not receive prenatal care. On examination, the child's growth parameters are below the 50th percentile for her age. She exhibits nummular keratitis, notched upper incisors and molars, and bilateral tibial bowing. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital syphilis

 

Option A: Congenital syphilis

 

  • This can present with variety of symptoms, many of which are consistent with the findings in this case.
  • Nummular keratitis, dental anomalies such as notched teeth (Hutchinson's teeth), and bilateral tibial bowing (sabre shins) are classic signs of late congenital syphilis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Congenital toxoplasmosis

 

  • It typically presents with chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and intracranial calcifications.
  • Dental and bone deformities are not characteristic findings of congenital toxoplasmosis.

 

Option C. Congenital rubella syndrome can lead to cataracts, heart defects, and deafness, known as the classic triad. The findings in this patient do not align with this triad.

 

Option D. Congenital cytomegalovirus (CMV)

 

  • This infection can cause a range of symptoms including hearing loss, microcephaly, and hepatosplenomegaly.
  • While it can lead to retinitis, it is less likely to cause the dental and skeletal abnormalities seen in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The presence of nummular keratitis, Hutchinson's teeth, and sabre shins in a young child with behavioral changes and a history of no prenatal care strongly suggests a diagnosis of congenital syphilis.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 293

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.29

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1456

choices.text: Secondary
Latent - Early
Primary
Latent - Late

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presents to the clinic with painless lesions in the genital area. The patient reports having unprotected sexual intercourse several months ago. On examination, you observe multiple, broad, moist, flat-topped papules as shown below. No other symptoms are present. The patient's blood test is positive for Treponema pallidum. What is the stage of syphilis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Secondary

 

Option A. Secondary Syphilis:

 

  • The patient's presentation is consistent with secondary syphilis, characterized by the presence of condyloma lata.
  • These lesions are broad, moist, flat-topped papules and are highly infectious.
  • Secondary syphilis can also present with a rash, mucosal lesions, and lymphadenopathy.
  • It typically occurs weeks to months after the initial infection.

Note - Cutaneous Lesions of Secondary Syphilis are not infectious as they do not have enough Treponemas. Exceptions are Condyloma Lata & Mucous Patches which are highly Infectious. 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Latent - Early:

 

  • This stage is asymptomatic and occurs after the secondary stage.
  • There are no clinical signs during the latent phase, but serologic tests for syphilis are positive.

 

Option C. Primary Syphilis:

 

  • Primary syphilis is characterized by the presence of a chancre, a painless ulcer at the site of inoculation.
  • The chancre typically appears 3 weeks after infection and resolves within 3-6 weeks.

 

Option D. Latent - Late:

 

  • This is the asymptomatic stage that can last for years.
  • Late latent syphilis is less likely to be transmitted and may proceed to tertiary syphilis, which can affect multiple organ systems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Condyloma lata is a hallmark of secondary syphilis, presenting as broad, moist, wart-like lesions, typically appearing weeks to months following the initial Treponema pallidum infection.

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 270

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.12

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1451

choices.text: Sites usually affected are penis or vulva
Extragenital lesions occur over lips, finger
Chancre is a painless indurated ulcer, giving button-like feeling
Regional lymph nodes may become palpable as painful rubbery swelling

questions.text: Manifestations of primary chancre in syphilis may include each of the following EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Regional lymph nodes may become palpable as painful rubbery swelling.

 

Option D. Regional lymph nodes may become palpable as painful rubbery swelling

 

  • While regional lymph nodes often become enlarged and palpable in primary syphilis, they are usually painless and have a firm, rubbery texture. Painful lymphadenopathy is not characteristic of primary syphilis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sites usually affected are penis or vulva:

 

  • The primary chancre of syphilis typically occurs at the site of Treponema pallidum inoculation, commonly affecting the penis in men and vulva in women. This is the classic presentation of a primary syphilis lesion.
     

Option B. Extragenital lesions occur over lips, finger:

 

  • While less common, primary chancres can indeed occur at extragenital sites, such as the lips or fingers. This happens due to direct contact with the spirochete at these locations.
     

Option C. Chancre is a painless indurated ulcer, giving button-like feeling:

 

  • The primary chancre is typically a painless, indurated ulcer with a clean base and firm borders, often described as having a button-like consistency.
     

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary chancre in syphilis is characterized by a painless, indurated ulcer at the site of infection, commonly on the genitals but possibly extragenitally, and is accompanied by painless, firm, rubbery regional lymphadenopathy.

 

Ref:  Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 267

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.8

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1450

choices.text: TPHA
DGI Examination
VDRL
TPI

questions.text: Monitoring of response to treatment in syphilis is by?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) VDRL

 

Option C. VDRL (Venereal Disease Research Laboratory):

 

  • The VDRL test is a nontreponemal serological test used to monitor the effectiveness of treatment in patients with syphilis.
  • Titers typically decrease with effective therapy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. TPHA (Treponema Pallidum Hemagglutination Assay):

 

  • TPHA is a treponemal test used for the detection of syphilis. It is used for confirmatory testing and remains positive for life even after successful treatment, so it is not useful for monitoring response to treatment.

 

Option B. DGI Examination:

 

  • DGI, or Dark Ground Illumination, is used to visualize live spirochetes in samples from lesions in syphilis. While it can demonstrate the presence of spirochetes, it is not typically used for monitoring the response to treatment.

 

Option D. TPI (Treponema pallidum immobilization test):

 

  • This test is historically significant but is now largely obsolete and not used in current practice for the diagnosis or monitoring of syphilis.


Educational Objective:

 

  • The VDRL test is used to monitor the response to treatment in syphilis, as titers are expected to decrease following successful therapy, indicating a decrease in the antigen load.

 

Ref: Sexually Transmitted Diseases and HIV/AIDS by Vinod K Sharma, 2nd edition, Page no 269

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition page no 29.22

Bolognia Textbook of Dermatology 4th edition Page no 1456
